VP.content: Husserl’s Ausdruck (expression) vs. Anzeichen (indication), unlike Ausdruck, Anzeichen is deprived of Sinn or Bedeutung ——Bedeutung translated into French or English as signification does not allow this thought, for we can never say a sign does not have signification, so Derrida translates Bedeutung as “vouloir-dire”
VP.linkedContent: Husserl’s Ausdruck (expression) vs. Anzeichen (indication), unlike Ausdruck, Anzeichen is deprived of Sinn or Bedeutung ——Bedeutung translated into French or English as signification does not allow this thought, for we can never say a sign does not have signification, so Derrida translates Bedeutung as “vouloir-dire”

VP.content: Ausdruck as spoken
VP.linkedContent: Ausdruck as spoken

VP.content: Bedeutung reserved for ideal sense content of verbal expression; Sinn covers whole noematic sphere, including non-expressive stratum [in Logical Inv…, Husserl yet to make this distinction]
VP.linkedContent: Bedeutung reserved for ideal sense content of verbal expression; Sinn covers whole noematic sphere, including non-expressive stratum [in Logical Inv…, Husserl yet to make this distinction]

VP.content: one and same sign can be indicative or expressive depending on intentional lived-experience that animates it
VP.linkedContent: one and same sign can be indicative or expressive depending on intentional lived-experience that animates it

VP.content: Husserl says that all expression is in an entanglement (Verflechtung) with indication in communicative discourse > allzeit verflochten ist (always contaminated), but/so Husserl separates expression from communication
VP.linkedContent: Husserl says that all expression is in an entanglement (Verflechtung) with indication in communicative discourse > allzeit verflochten ist (always contaminated), but/so Husserl separates expression from communication

VP.content: rigorous distinction btwn indication and expression (which are intimately associated) is only possible through juridical and phenomenological means: the analysis occurs in hiatus btwn fact & right, essence & existence, reality and intentional function
VP.linkedContent: rigorous distinction btwn indication and expression (which are intimately associated) is only possible through juridical and phenomenological means: the analysis occurs in hiatus btwn fact & right, essence & existence, reality and intentional function

VP.content: for Husserl, Bedeutung can be expressed w/out communication, can occur outside entanglement w/ indication, in the “solitary life of the soul,” when the outside is suspended, an interiority, self-proximity, an ownness (Eigenheit) > this paradox is phenomenology
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, Bedeutung can be expressed w/out communication, can occur outside entanglement w/ indication, in the “solitary life of the soul,” when the outside is suspended, an interiority, self-proximity, an ownness (Eigenheit) > this paradox is phenomenology

VP.content: Hinzulenken, Hinzeigen (expressive referral) vs. Anzeigen (indicative referral)
VP.linkedContent: Hinzulenken, Hinzeigen (expressive referral) vs. Anzeigen (indicative referral)

VP.content: Husserl does not pose question about Zeigen in general
VP.linkedContent: Husserl does not pose question about Zeigen in general

VP.content: [under Husserl’s definitions, would (phonetic) writing lose all its expressive capacity (non-phonetic)?]
VP.linkedContent: [under Husserl’s definitions, would (phonetic) writing lose all its expressive capacity (non-phonetic)?]

VP.content: phenomenology belongs to metaphysics > because of exteriority of indication in relation to expression
VP.linkedContent: phenomenology belongs to metaphysics > because of exteriority of indication in relation to expression

VP.content: indicative allusion (Hinweis), apodictic demonstration (Beweis) > in latter case, the “because” links evident/ideal necessities beyond the empirical
VP.linkedContent: indicative allusion (Hinweis), apodictic demonstration (Beweis) > in latter case, the “because” links evident/ideal necessities beyond the empirical

VP.content: by making indication exterior, extrinsic, it will fall prey to all empiricity that is reduced in the reduction: factuality, non-evidence, mundane existence, essential non-necessity, etc.
VP.linkedContent: by making indication exterior, extrinsic, it will fall prey to all empiricity that is reduced in the reduction: factuality, non-evidence, mundane existence, essential non-necessity, etc.

VP.content: Husserl keeps signification outside self-presence of transcendental life
VP.linkedContent: Husserl keeps signification outside self-presence of transcendental life

VP.content: Husserl develops parallelism of Ausdruck and Anzeichen in the hiatus btwn them
VP.linkedContent: Husserl develops parallelism of Ausdruck and Anzeichen in the hiatus btwn them

VP.content: [moving from commentary to interpretation] if hiatus is responsible for problematic of reduction, then reduction can’t be prior, must be merged w/ speech, power of expression
VP.linkedContent: [moving from commentary to interpretation] if hiatus is responsible for problematic of reduction, then reduction can’t be prior, must be merged w/ speech, power of expression

VP.content: Derrida: although there is no discourse w/out expressive kernel, we could almost say la totalité du discours est prise dans une trame indicative
VP.linkedContent: Derrida: although there is no discourse w/out expressive kernel, we could almost say la totalité du discours est prise dans une trame indicative

VP.content: for Husserl, ex-pression moves outside (an absolutely original outside, neither nature, world, nor exterior to consciousness), toward an ideal ob-ject, but remains w/in “solitary life,” w/in noetico-noematic sphere of consciousness, remains in the “phenomenological” voice
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, ex-pression moves outside (an absolutely original outside, neither nature, world, nor exterior to consciousness), toward an ideal ob-ject, but remains w/in “solitary life,” w/in noetico-noematic sphere of consciousness, remains in the “phenomenological” voice

VP.content: intentionality in every expression explains Derrida’s choice of vouloir-dire for Bedeutung
VP.linkedContent: intentionality in every expression explains Derrida’s choice of vouloir-dire for Bedeutung

VP.content: everything indicative, empirical, everything that physically incarnates expression, is foreign to expressivity, to pure intention
VP.linkedContent: everything indicative, empirical, everything that physically incarnates expression, is foreign to expressivity, to pure intention

VP.content: for Husserl, facial expressions are death of self-presence, have no Bedeutung
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, facial expressions are death of self-presence, have no Bedeutung

VP.content: Bedeutung as essence of language, as its telos > indication as failure of this telos ——non-expressive signs want to say (veulent dire) (bedeuten) only insofar as one can make them say (on peut leur faire dire) what was murmuring in them
VP.linkedContent: Bedeutung as essence of language, as its telos > indication as failure of this telos ——non-expressive signs want to say (veulent dire) (bedeuten) only insofar as one can make them say (on peut leur faire dire) what was murmuring in them

VP.content: “they [facial expressions] do not want to say (vouloir-dire) anything because they do not want (vouloir-dire) to say anything.”
VP.linkedContent: “they [facial expressions] do not want to say (vouloir-dire) anything because they do not want (vouloir-dire) to say anything.”

VP.content: if, for Husserl, interpretation of someone’s “expression” can only be indicative, is there something in the relation to others that makes indication irreducible?
VP.linkedContent: if, for Husserl, interpretation of someone’s “expression” can only be indicative, is there something in the relation to others that makes indication irreducible?

VP.content: what separates expression from indication is “what we could call the immediate non-self-presence of the living present”
VP.linkedContent: what separates expression from indication is “what we could call the immediate non-self-presence of the living present”

VP.content: difference btwn indication and expression is functional or intentional not substantial
VP.linkedContent: difference btwn indication and expression is functional or intentional not substantial

VP.content: manifestation function (kundgebende Funktion), indication, physicality, whenever living spirituality is not fully present
VP.linkedContent: manifestation function (kundgebende Funktion), indication, physicality, whenever living spirituality is not fully present

VP.content: pure expressivity is pure active intention (spirit, psyche, life, will); all indication takes place in nature, space, world
VP.linkedContent: pure expressivity is pure active intention (spirit, psyche, life, will); all indication takes place in nature, space, world

VP.content: physicality of language seems absent in interior monologue, presence not driven off course by “existence” of word; word is perfectly same inside
VP.linkedContent: physicality of language seems absent in interior monologue, presence not driven off course by “existence” of word; word is perfectly same inside

VP.content: [now] expression escapes even the logic of the sign, which is always indicative
VP.linkedContent: [now] expression escapes even the logic of the sign, which is always indicative

VP.content: Hinzeigen (“monstration"), Anzeigen (referral); for Husserl, to keep self-presence from being absolutely nothing, there must be a Hinzeigen w/out Anzeigen
VP.linkedContent: Hinzeigen (“monstration"), Anzeigen (referral); for Husserl, to keep self-presence from being absolutely nothing, there must be a Hinzeigen w/out Anzeigen

VP.content: [Derrida’s interpretation] if all discourse belongs to order of representation, then “actual” language as imaginary as imaginary discourse, imaginary discourse as actual as actual discourse
VP.linkedContent: [Derrida’s interpretation] if all discourse belongs to order of representation, then “actual” language as imaginary as imaginary discourse, imaginary discourse as actual as actual discourse

VP.content: for Husserl, “if representation in indicative discourse is false, in monologue it is useless,” subject has no need to indicate to himself > w/out reason, w/out purpose, “zwecklos,” this purposelessness is the non-alterity in identity of presence
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, “if representation in indicative discourse is false, in monologue it is useless,” subject has no need to indicate to himself > w/out reason, w/out purpose, “zwecklos,” this purposelessness is the non-alterity in identity of presence

VP.content: [now] phenomenological [absolute] “silence” of self-relation must exclude not only the other (indication) but also expressive language itself > agency of voice btwn these 2 exclusions
VP.linkedContent: [now] phenomenological [absolute] “silence” of self-relation must exclude not only the other (indication) but also expressive language itself > agency of voice btwn these 2 exclusions

VP.content: [w/ difficult logic] Derrida shows that somewhere in Husserl, Zeigen (relation to other as indicative monstration) includes both indication and expression > and wouldn’t Zeigen be indication then? [see pp. 36-7]
VP.linkedContent: [w/ difficult logic] Derrida shows that somewhere in Husserl, Zeigen (relation to other as indicative monstration) includes both indication and expression > and wouldn’t Zeigen be indication then? [see pp. 36-7]

VP.content: wouldn’t [contra Husserl] universal element of expressivity forbid fulfillment of Bedeutung when we say “I” in solitude, dispossessing the subject of full intuition of “I”?
VP.linkedContent: wouldn’t [contra Husserl] universal element of expressivity forbid fulfillment of Bedeutung when we say “I” in solitude, dispossessing the subject of full intuition of “I”?

VP.content: expression is always “expressing itself about something”
VP.linkedContent: expression is always “expressing itself about something”

VP.content: Husserlian distinction btwn the manifested (subjective) and the expressed as named: “I” is always an indicative monstration; “glass of water, please” names the thing and manifests the desire
VP.linkedContent: Husserlian distinction btwn the manifested (subjective) and the expressed as named: “I” is always an indicative monstration; “glass of water, please” names the thing and manifests the desire

VP.content: if Husserl bracketed what glossematicians call “substance of expression” he would threaten his entire project
VP.linkedContent: if Husserl bracketed what glossematicians call “substance of expression” he would threaten his entire project

VP.content: Husserl manages to reduce medium of language at the moment he asserts his phonocentrism, absolute proximity of signifier/signified, signifier’s erasure in presence
VP.linkedContent: Husserl manages to reduce medium of language at the moment he asserts his phonocentrism, absolute proximity of signifier/signified, signifier’s erasure in presence

VP.content: Derrida notes uniqueness of Husserl’s division between intuition and intentionality, that the “fulfilling” intuition is not essential to the expression, to the intention of meaning: this allows for a pure logical grammar: absence of object is not absence of meaning
VP.linkedContent: Derrida notes uniqueness of Husserl’s division between intuition and intentionality, that the “fulfilling” intuition is not essential to the expression, to the intention of meaning: this allows for a pure logical grammar: absence of object is not absence of meaning

VP.content: non-coincidence of ideal expression, ideal Bedeutung and the object ——pure logical grammar depends on distinction btwn Widersinnigkeit and Sinnlosigkeit, expression can be widersinnig w/out becoming non-sense (Unsinn)
VP.linkedContent: non-coincidence of ideal expression, ideal Bedeutung and the object ——pure logical grammar depends on distinction btwn Widersinnigkeit and Sinnlosigkeit, expression can be widersinnig w/out becoming non-sense (Unsinn)

VP.content: [now] in presence (of object), intentionality and intuition fuse [?], and its structure disappears, can they ever be fused in intentional meaning can function w/out intuition [?]
VP.linkedContent: [now] in presence (of object), intentionality and intuition fuse [?], and its structure disappears, can they ever be fused in intentional meaning can function w/out intuition [?]

VP.content: that pure grammar can work w/out object, w/out intuition, leads Derrida to the privilege of writing as the common name for all signification, must work after death
VP.linkedContent: that pure grammar can work w/out object, w/out intuition, leads Derrida to the privilege of writing as the common name for all signification, must work after death

VP.content: for Husserl, the Bedeutung of “I,” for the one who speaks, is realized > immediate representation of our personality; but, isn’t every expression only possible in relation to absence of object, absence of intuition, meaning, in this example, the absence of “I”?
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, the Bedeutung of “I,” for the one who speaks, is realized > immediate representation of our personality; but, isn’t every expression only possible in relation to absence of object, absence of intuition, meaning, in this example, the absence of “I”?

VP.content: Husserl: “I” is “a universally operative indexical of the fact”
VP.linkedContent: Husserl: “I” is “a universally operative indexical of the fact”

VP.content: Husserl’s contradiction: “I” must always be new but doesn’t ideal nature of Bedeutung exclude the “always new” > Derrida uses Husserl’s logic against him, explaining that we understand “I,” even when “I am dead,” because intention does not require intuition
VP.linkedContent: Husserl’s contradiction: “I” must always be new but doesn’t ideal nature of Bedeutung exclude the “always new” > Derrida uses Husserl’s logic against him, explaining that we understand “I,” even when “I am dead,” because intention does not require intuition

VP.content: Husserl: “we are infinitely distant from this ideal” that of “truths in themselves” [w/out contamination of occasional expressions] > this is the teleological structure of phenomenology
VP.linkedContent: Husserl: “we are infinitely distant from this ideal” that of “truths in themselves” [w/out contamination of occasional expressions] > this is the teleological structure of phenomenology

PPHS.content: Derrida’s translation of Bedeutung as vouloir-dire [re: Husserl’s Logi…] is also valid for Hegel > Hegel accords to Bedeutung name & rank of soul (Seele)
PPHS.linkedContent: Derrida’s translation of Bedeutung as vouloir-dire [re: Husserl’s Logi…] is also valid for Hegel > Hegel accords to Bedeutung name & rank of soul (Seele)

PPHS.content: signifying intention (bedeuten) over body (signifier, from Cratylus, sēma/sōma (tomb/body), sign as tomb, prison) > Husserl, Saussure, Hegel
PPHS.linkedContent: signifying intention (bedeuten) over body (signifier, from Cratylus, sēma/sōma (tomb/body), sign as tomb, prison) > Husserl, Saussure, Hegel

PPHS.content: acc. Hegel, symbols (triangle, lion, fox) possess the Bedeutung they’re expressing
PPHS.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, symbols (triangle, lion, fox) possess the Bedeutung they’re expressing

PPHS.content: for Derrida, contents of semiology cannot be exhausted by the metaphysical theory which regulates bedeuten (meaning) by the telos of speech

POS.content: Husserl’s progression from no difference then difference btwn Sinn and Bedeutung (meaning isolated from enunciation [intention of enunciation] of signification) [Frege]

POS.content: phenomenology’s concept of “meaning” appears wider (i.e. all experiences) than Sausurre’s, but it also claims that signifier is exteriorization (Äusserung) or expression (Ausdruck) of signified
POS.linkedContent: phenomenology’s concept of “meaning” appears wider (i.e. all experiences) than Sausurre’s, but it also claims that signifier is exteriorization (Äusserung) or expression (Ausdruck) of signified

POS.content: Husserl’s Bedeutung becomes pure signified, wouldn’t be in differential tissue of gram, trace, spacing
